So - is this a Thunderbird problem or a Windows 11 problem?

content: Is this a POP account? If so, my inference is that you have, in prior setup, set the account to leave on server. Since POP defaults to downloading unread messages, that is the challenge it appears that you face. Thunderbird controls the process of determining which messages to download by maintaining a file called popstate.dat. Left to its default, it will download all messages that this copy of Thunderbird has not downloaded. Since you don't want to do that, you can edit the popstate file with instructions from this URL: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Popstate.dat
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you for sharing this, as I'm sure the developers will be interested. My understanding is that DA WCAG applies to websites, not to email clients, but I'm not well-versed in this. You will help us if you will point to the compliance standards requirements that affect threading. This is the support forum, but I assure you that such information, once you provide it, will be forwarded to appropriate personnel. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: The WCAG and ADA standard does not specify threading. It relates to creating changes that require having pre- knowledge and knowing multiple steps to find accessible functions. The need to do multiple steps for every folder is the barrier. If there was a one-step process for each folder, that would likely be in compliance. The critical part is the solution is not obvious. One needs to know that the solution is in the View part of the Menu options, then Sort By (when the Threads option looks obvious but does not lead to a solution) then finally Unthread. To start the whole process, one must KNOW, Have preknowledge, that those three short horizontal bars as an icon lead to a Menu. WCAG requires the solution to have an obvious path. A right click on a folder with Threading options would be appropriate. Instead, the options are divided into may different multi-step paths. WCAG requires an option for "Text under an Icon". Not just "Hover and text will show up" Many have no idea that those three short horizontal bars mean anything. Mozilla deleted these options about 4 or 5 years ago. We have a large population of ASD, Autism Spectrum Disorder, who may be literal thinkers and others who have inabilities to memorize processes that are not obvious or an inability to translate Icons into a text based concept. These fancy threading functions should be the options, not the default.
creator: MarkinIdaho

content:
This happens when the profile is not where Thunderbird expects to see it. Thunderbird looks at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini for the location of the profile. The error message indicates that the profiles.ini has been changed or that the profile isn't where it was when backed up. This may happen if copied to drive prior to installing thunderbird. If all is intact, you should be able to - install thunderbird first - copy the folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird (with prompt for overwrites)

Another option is to delete the folder and restart Thunderbird and click tools>import>import from another installation and then select the explicit profile.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you for the reply but no, it simply doesn't work. It doesn't matter how the copying takes place Thunderbird keeps complaining "...the profile is missing or inaccessible".

I've noticed there is also an "%AppData%/Local/Thunderbird/Profiles" directory containing what seem to be similar profiles to the ones contained under"%AppData%/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles".

content:
Tools -> Developer Tools -> Error Console -> Errors shows "Uncaught (in promise) DOMException: Could not open the file at Z:\Thunderbird\prefs.js"

My original %AppData%/Roaming/Thunderbird/profiles.ini shows ...>>> [General] StartWithLastProfile=1

[Profile0] Name=default IsRelative=1 Path=Profiles/miymmxk2.default ...>>>

Which profile do I start with please?
creator: vladd2

content: I believe the problem isn't the profile, it is the profiles.ini file that you are importing. - start thunderbird - click tools>import>import from another thunderbird installation - click choose a profile at this point, locate the profile in your backup that is at ...appdata\roaming\thunerbird\profile\<profilename> where 'profile name' is the 11gb one (there may be more than one profile in the .... thunderbird\profiles folder) Doing it this way causes Thunderbird to update the profiles.ini properly.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you so much David, importing everything ultimately worked.

This is what I did:

-installed Thunderbird (same version as source) on target (new Win11 computer) -did not create a profile -mapped %AppData%/Roaming/Thunderbird as a remote drive from old (Win10) computer -imported everything (Tools->Import) from mapped drive/Profiles/*.Default User directory (in my case "t1Djir79.Default User" -Thunderbird copied everything over cleanly -And it restarted upon completion.

Thank you again,
creator: vladd2

content: I am very pleased that all worked out okay. :)
